Hi,
	I don't know for a fact, but Hebbian learning is presumably intended 
for use with all or nothing neurones, e.g.which turn on completely 
when the input passes a threshold, a step activation function.

	They might also be intended for use in time-resolved systems, e.g. 
where a neurone fires at the time that its inputs pass the threshold, 
stays on for some period and then turns off and cannot be reactivated 
until some other period has elapsed.  This effectively forbids the 
"both these neurones are always on and hence develop a weighting 
between them" scenario.

	It is also the way that biological neurones work.

	Is Hebbian learning directional?  e.g. if a and b are on together 
then does that create as much of a a->b weight as a b->a 
weight?  That sounds like more of a classifier approach than a controller...

	How about if only some of the neurones were Hebbian.  Sort of have 
non-H in the body of a "module" and then H nodes to wire up the 
inputs and outputs.

	Ian
